Situation1: They greet a few customers politely while scanning items at a quiet store.
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: An individual arrives at the church in a state of acute emotional distress seeking immediate spiritual support for a crisis.
Story: I stood behind the register, the soft beep of the scanner marking each item as I smiled at the few customers trickling through the store. “Have a great day,” I said, handing a receipt to an elderly woman, trying to make her feel seen, as I always did. My manager expected me to be friendly, efficient, and present for every customer, no matter how slow the day was. Just as I finished with the last customer, my phone buzzed in my pocket—a message from the church secretary: “Someone is here, very upset, asking for you. Says it’s urgent.” My heart clenched. As a priest, I was supposed to be there for people in crisis, to offer comfort and guidance when they needed it most. But I was still on shift, and my manager frowned on any distractions. I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of both uniforms pressing down on me. The store was quiet, but I couldn’t just leave. Yet, someone was waiting for me, desperate for help. I gripped the counter, torn between the expectations of kindness at the register and the deeper call to serve a soul in pain.
